## Motivation: "We can compute what we cannot yet see" 

### The gap between atomistic simulations and 3D atomic resolution imaging

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}
- ML potentials are now probing 10<sup>8</sup> atoms at picosecond‚Äìnanosecond time‚Äësteps  
- 2024: [1] polycrystalline Cu, 100M atoms
- 2023: [2] SARS-CoV-2 Spike glycoprotein in water, 100M atoms

![](./images/md_sim_100M.png){width="850px"}

<figcaption style="text-align: center;">[1]</figcaption>
:::
::: {.column width="50%" .fragment}
- 3D atomic resolution imaging  has been limited to max. volumes of ~(15nm)<sup>3</sup>, 10<sup>4</sup> - 10<sup>5</sup> atoms
![](./images/aet_1.png){width="420px"}
![](./images/aet_2.png){width="420px"}
<figcaption style="text-align: center;">Adapted from [3]</figcaption>
:::
::: 

 

::: {.callout-note .fragment}
Ptychographic electron tomography can be developed into an experimental counterpart that can shorten this gap by combining ML-enhanced reconstructions, automation & dose‚Äëefficient scanning.
:::
 
::: aside
[1] Shang et al. 10.1109/SC41406.2024.0001 (2024) [2] Musaelian et al. arXiv:2304.10061v (2023) [3] Zhou, J. MRS Bulletin 45, 290‚Äì297 (2020).
:::

## End-to-end reconstruction - putting all pieces together

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
Fully E2E-MSPT reconstruction includes

1. affine resampling of potential volume<br>
2. z-resampling of potential volume (save compute)<br>
3. batch-croppping and mixed-state multi-slice model<br>
4. far-field propagation<br>
5. gradient backpropagation through full model 
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](./extracted_media/image88.png){width="70%"}
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note .fragment}
The most accurate approximation for 4D-STEM tomography to-date.

Difficulty: initialization of the model parameters
::: 

::: aside
@You_Romanov_Pelz_2024
:::

<img src="./extracted_media/image169.png" style="position: absolute; top: 0px; right: -100px; width: 150px; z-index: 10;">

## Atomic resolution tomography has been a postdoc-intensive business 

[Sanchez-Santolino et al. Nano Letters (2025)]{style="color: gold;"}: "This approach, first suggested by Li and Maiden and recently demonstrated in some particularly challenging systems by Pelz et al. allows one to gain the full three-dimensional knowledge via a tomographic approach [...]"

<br>

So far:  

- highly trained microscopists required for ADF-STEM/4D-STEM tilt series data acquisition 
- manual collection & long algorithm chain hinder widespread adoption 

- How can we make it more accessible and less challenging? 

::: {.callout-note .fragment} 
Automated 4D-STEM tomography<br> 
and end-to-end reconstruction are<br>
key to democratizing atomic resolution tomography<br>
:::

## Summary
::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="66%"}
- Demonstrated atomic structure determination by ptychographic electron tomography with 1.6√Ö resolution
- Multi-slice ptychographic tomography results show:
  - Scaling to volumes beyond 3x the depth of field limit
  - Signal of single oxygen atoms sufficient 
 
- End-to-end learning alleviates the missing wedge problem and enables near-isotropic 3D resolution
- Automation should democratize the method in the near future
